summary: This is a court order from Judge Kenneth A. Marra granting a motion to produce the non-prosecution agreement between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Jeffrey Epstein. The order establishes strict protective procedures for disclosing the agreement to petitioners (Jane Does 1 and 2) and other identified victims, prohibiting them from sharing its terms with third parties.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida. The order concerns the production of this agreement to victims.

persons.name: Kenneth A. Marra
persons.context: The judge who issued the order granting the motion to produce the non-prosecution agreement and establishing protective procedures for its disclosure.

persons.name: Jane Doe 1
persons.context: One of the petitioners seeking production of the non-prosecution agreement, identified as a victim of Jeffrey Epstein by the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Jane Doe 2
persons.context: One of the petitioners seeking production of the non-prosecution agreement, identified as a victim of Jeffrey Epstein by the U.S. Attorney's Office.

connections.description: Jane Doe 1 is identified by the U.S. Attorney's Office as a victim of Jeffrey Epstein.
Jane Doe 2 is identified by the U.S. Attorney's Office as a victim of Jeffrey Epstein.
Judge Marra issued a court order concerning the disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement involving Epstein.

events.title: Court Orders Production of Epstein NPA
events.description: Judge Kenneth A. Marra grants a motion filed by petitioners (Jane Does 1 and 2) and orders the U.S. Attorney's Office to produce the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein under a protective order.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of Florida
keyFacts: A federal judge ordered the U.S. Attorney's Office to produce the secret non-prosecution agreement (NPA) it had with Jeffrey Epstein.
The order was granted in response to a motion filed by two victims identified as Jane Does 1 and 2.
The production was subject to a strict protective order prohibiting the petitioners and other victims from disclosing the agreement's terms to third parties.
The order indicates the existence of a non-prosecution agreement was known to the court and victims' attorneys by August 2008, but its contents were still shielded from public view.
The document is a key piece of evidence showing judicial oversight and victim access efforts regarding the controversial plea deal.
